key_issues: Here are the main legal issues:
* Whether the respondent's failure to file evidence in support of opposition within the prescribed time period resulted in abandonment of the opposition proceedings.
* Whether the notice of counter-statement by the respondent triggered the two-month period for filing evidence as per Rule 45(1) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017.
* Construction and application of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 regarding evidence in support of opposition.
* Effect of deemed abandonment of opposition under Rule 45(2) on further proceedings.
* Whether the respondent's intention to rely on facts mentioned in the Notice of Opposition is sufficient to prevent deemed abandonment.
* Applicability of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 and the Rules made thereunder.
* Scope and validity of registration of trade mark "LIVGUARD ZING" by Respondent 1.
* Impact of rule 45(2) on pending opposition proceedings.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: M/S V-GUARD INDUSTRIES LTD. v. M/S LIVGUARD ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES PVT LTD & ANR.**

**Background:** This is an appeal against the order of the learned Deputy Registrar of Trademarks, dated August 2018, passed in Application No. 2772497 filed by Respondent 1, M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd., seeking registration of their mark "LIVGUARD ZING" in respect of batteries, invertors and like goods.

**Legal Issues:** The main legal issue in this case revolves around the interpretation of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules 2017. The rule states that if an opponent takes no action within two months from service of a copy of the counterstatement, he shall be deemed to have abandoned his opposition.

**Facts:**

* Respondent 1 filed an application for registration of their mark "LIVGUARD ZING" in July 2014.
* The application was published on February 15, 2016, inviting opposition.
* Appellant M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. filed a notice of opposition on June 2, 2016.
* Respondent 1 filed a counter statement on March 7, 2018.
* The notice of counter statement was served on the appellant electronically on the same day.

**Arguments:**

* Appellant argued that since Respondent 1 did not file any evidence in support of their opposition within two months from service of the counterstatement, they should be deemed to have abandoned their opposition under Rule 45.
* Respondent 1 argued that since they filed a counter statement on March 7, 2018, which was served on the appellant electronically, their time for filing evidence began only from that date.

**Court Findings:**

* The Court held that Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules is ambiguous and has been worded in an unfortunate manner.
* The Court observed that the rule requires the opponent to leave evidence with the Registrar or intimate to the Registrar and applicant that they do not desire to adduce evidence but intend to rely on facts stated in the notice of opposition.
* The Court noted that Respondent 1 failed to comply with Rule 45 by not filing any evidence within two months from service of the counterstatement.

**Decision:**

* The Court held that since Respondent 1 did not file any evidence in support of their opposition, they should be deemed to have abandoned their opposition under Rule 45.
* The Court dismissed the appeal and allowed the application for registration of the mark "LIVGUARD ZING".
* There was no order as to costs.

**Conclusion:**

This case highlights the importance of carefully drafting trade mark rules to ensure clarity and avoid ambiguity. The court's interpretation of Rule 45 may have significant implications for opponents in future trademark opposition proceedings.

“45. 
Evidence in support of opposition.— (1) Within two 
months from  service of a copy of the counterstatement, the 
opponent shall either leave with the Registrar, such evidence by 
way of affidavit as he may desire to adduce in support of his

writing that he does not desire to adduce evidence in support of his 
opposition but intends to rely on the facts stated in the notice of 
opposition. He shall deliver to the applicant copies of any evidence 
including exhibits, if any, that he leaves with the Registrar under 
this sub-rule and intimate the Registrar in writing of such delivery. 
 
If an opponent takes no action under sub-rule (1) within the 
time mentioned therein, he shall be deemed to have abandoned his 
opposition.”

expression “leave with the Registrar”. This is an expression to which

Rules which deals with “leaving of documents” etc. and reads thus: 
“8. 
Leaving of documents, etc.— All applications, notices, 
statements or other documents or any fees authorised or required 
by the Act or the rules to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or 
to the Trade Marks Registry in relation to a trademark on the 
Register of trademarks on the notified date or for which an 
application for registration is pending on, or is made on or after the 
notified date, shall be made, served, left or sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry: 
 
Provided that the Registrar may, by notification in the journal, 
permit the filing of certain forms or documents, other than the 
application for the registration of a trademark in any other office of 
the Trade Marks Registry.” 
 
7. 
Unfortunately, Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules is just as 
nebulous as Rule 45.  It requires the opponent, opposing the 
registration of a trade mark, to “leave with the Registrar”, evidence by 
way of affidavit.  It is difficult to understand the expression “leave 
with the Registrar”.  At any rate, it is not an expression which should 
ordinarily find place in a legislative document. 
 
8. 
The case of the appellant, as argued by Ms. Bhabna Das, 
learned Counsel for the appellant, and as set out in the present appeal, 
is that 7th May 2018 being the last date by which the evidence in 
opposition was required to be filed by the appellant, attempts were 
made to upload the evidence on the website of the Registrar of Trade 
Marks, but that, as the website was non-functional, this could not be 
done.  As a result, submits Ms. Bhabna Das, the evidence was sent to 
the office of the Registrar by courier.  It is an admitted position that 
the evidence in opposition as sent by the appellant was, in fact, 
received by the office of the learned Registrar on 10th May 2018, i.e.,

mere three days beyond the last date for “leaving” of the evidence.  
 
9. 
As is apparent, the impugned order has proceeded on the 
premise that, as the evidence in terms of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark 
Rules had not been filed within two months from the service of the 
counter statement of Respondent 1 on the appellant, the opposition of 
the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned by application of 
sub-rule (2) of Rule 45.  
 
10. 
At a bare glance, the impugned order is incorrect, as Rule 45(1) 
does not use the expression “filed”.  What Rule 45(1) requires is that 
the evidence must be “left with the Registrar”.  Where the statute is 
ambiguous, the benefit of ambiguity has to go to the citizen. This 
would be especially so where the statute confers a valuable 
commercial right on the citizen. It cannot be gainsaid that, having 
submitted the notice of opposition, opposing the application of 
Respondent 1 for registration of the Trade Mark, the tendering of 
evidence in support of the opposition was a valuable commercial right 
which enured in favor of the opponent/appellant. There is no 
conceivable reason as to why, having filed the notice of opposition, 
the appellant would abandon the opposition.  That the appellant did 
not, in fact, do so, is manifest by the fact that, on 28th
 
 August 2018, 
the appellant filed an application for extension of time, purportedly 
under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the 
Trade Mark Rules, in Form TM-M, as required by the said rules.  
11. 
The application has not been considered by the learned Deputy 
Registrar while passing the impugned order. In the application, it was 
specifically submitted that the website of the learned Registrar of

The issue before the court is whether, in these circumstances 
and in the backdrop of the existing statutory scenario as contained in 
the Trade Marks Act and Trade Marks Rules, this Court should sustain 
the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar, vide the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018, to treat the opposition filed by the appellant, 
to the application of Respondent 1 seeking registration of the 
“LIVGUARD ZING” mark, as having been abandoned.  
14. 
Having heard Ms. Bhabna Das, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Jithin M George, learned Counsel for Respondent 1, 
in my considered opinion, the answer to this query has necessarily to 
be in the negative.  
 
15. 
Two issues would arise for consideration. The first is whether 
there was, in fact, delay on the part of the appellant in complying with 
the requirement of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules. The second is 
whether, assuming there was any such delay, the learned Registrar 
was empowered to condone the delay or to extend the time for 
compliance with Rule 45.  
 
16. 
Addressing the first issue first, Rule 45 (1) stipulates that,

within two months from service of the copy of the counter statement 
filed by the trade mark applicant, the opponent opposing the 
registration of the mark is required to leave, with the Registrar, 
evidence by way of affidavit in support of the opposition.  Rule 45(1) 
further requires the opponent to the registration of the trade mark to 
deliver, to the applicant seeking registration, copies of the affidavit 
left with the Registrar and to intimate the Registrar in that regard.   
 
17. 
Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules states that all documents, which 
are required “to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or to the Trade 
Marks Registry”, in respect of a Trade Mark in respect of which an 
application seeking registration is pending, “shall be made, served, 
left, or sent or paid to the appropriate office of the Trade Marks 
Registry”. 
 
18. 
As already observed, the provision is as nebulous as can be.  
The Rule, envelops, in one parenthesis, the expressions “made” 
“served”, “left”, “sent” and “paid” and refers to such making, serving, 
leaving, sending, or paying “to the appropriate office of the Trade 
Marks Registry”. 
 
19. 
Given the nature of these provisions and the fact that they affect 
a valuable right vested in an opponent who seeks to oppose the 
registration of a trade mark, I am of the considered opinion that, in the 
facts of the present case, the appellant won’t be entitled to the benefit 
of the ambiguity inherent in this provision.  
 
20. 
The appellant, in its application seeking extension of time as 
filed before the learned Deputy Registrar, as well as in the present 
Digitally Signed

Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---

 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021                                                                       Page 7 of 9  
 
   
appeal, has stated, on affidavit, that the attempts at e-filing of the 
evidence in support of the appellant’s objections, on 7th
 
 May 2018, 
could not succeed as the website of the learned Registrar of Trade 
Marks was non-functional.  The impugned order does not seek to 
discountenance this assertion.  Notice was issued in the present 
appeal, and there is no affidavit filed by way of response, denying this 
fact.  
21. 
There is no reason, therefore, for this Court to disbelieve the 
appellant and presume that, in fact, no attempt was made by the 
appellant to e-file the objections on 7th May 2018, especially as, on the 
very next day i.e., 8th May 2018, the objections were in fact sent by 
courier.  This is not, therefore, a case in which the appellant exhibited 
any callous or negligent indolence.   The fact that, on 8th May 2018, 
the appellant did indeed courier the evidence in support of the 
opposition to the office of the learned Registrar of Trade Marks, 
compels this Court to believe the assertion, in the present appeal, also 
contained in the application for extension of time filed before the 
learned Registrar with the evidence in support of the opposition was in 
fact forwarded to the office of the learned Registrar electronically on 
7th
 
 May 2018, but that the attempt could not succeed as the website 
was non-functional.  
22. 
Such an attempt, in my view, would fall within the broad 
embrace of the expression “made, served, left, sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry”, as employed in Rule 
8 of the Trade Marks Rules.  
 
23. 
Even otherwise, it is well-settled that, while procedural 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000136 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021                                                                       Page 8 of 9  
 
   
provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late, 
especially as, prima facie, the appellant did make efforts to “leave” the 
evidence in support of the opposition with the office of the learned 
Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.  
26. 
Resultantly, the learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take into 
account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a 
view thereon.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000136 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021                                                                       Page 9 of 9  
 
   
27. 
I am informed that, after the impugned order was passed, the 
mark of Respondent 1 has proceeded to registration.  
 
28. 
Needless to say, in view of the decision taken today, the 
registration of the Trade Mark shall remain subject to the outcome of 
the view to be taken by the learned Deputy Registrar on the opposition 
filed by the appellant.  
 
29. 
In order that equities are not unnecessarily prejudiced, the  
learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take a decision on the 
appellant's notice of opposition, after following due process in that 
regard, within a period of three months from today.  
 
30. 
For this purpose, both sides are directed to present themselves 
before the office of the learned Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on 
16th
 
 January 2023 at 11:00 a.m. 
31. 
The learned Deputy Registrar would proceed with the matter 
with all due expedition.  
 
32. 
Both sides are directed not to seek any adjournment from the 
learned Deputy Registrar. 
 
33. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no order as to 
costs.

**Case Summary**

Source: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd (2023/DHC/000136)

This case revolves around a trade mark registration application by M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd ("Respondent") for their mark "LIVGUARD ZING" in respect of batteries, invertors, and like goods.

**Case History:**

* Application No. 2772497 filed on July 11, 2014
* Published in the Register of Trade Marks on February 15, 2016
* Notice of opposition filed by M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd ("Appellant") on June 2, 2016
* Counter statement filed by Respondent on March 7, 2018

**Dispute:**

The Appellant opposed the registration of the mark "LIVGUARD ZING" under Section 21 of the Trade Mark Act, 1999.

**Ruling:**

On December 30, 2022 ( Judgment dated January 6, 2023), the learned Deputy Registrar of Trademarks deemed the opposition to have been abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 for lack of evidence or a statement indicating that the opponent no longer desired to adduce evidence.

**Orders:**

* The proceedings were initiated under Section 21 of the Trade Mark Act, 1999.
* There shall be no order as to costs in these proceedings.
* The application for registration of the mark "LIVGUARD ZING" is to proceed further as per rules.

The case is now before the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021 & I.A. 178/2023).

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Details:**

* **Case Name:** MS V-Guard Industries Ltd vs MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd
* **Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* **Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000136
* **C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) No:** 80/2021

**Background and Facts:**

The dispute revolves around a trademark registration. The appellant, MS V-Guard Industries Ltd, had opposed the application of Respondent 1 (MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd) for the registration of the trade mark "LivGuard". The opposition was based on various grounds.

However, due to technical issues with the Registrar of Trade Marks' website, the evidence in opposition could not be uploaded on time. Despite this, the evidence was sent by courier and received three days after the last date for submission.

**Legal Arguments:**

The appellant argued that Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules allows for filing evidence with the Registrar, but the expression "leave with the Registrar" is ambiguous. The respondent's impugned order deemed the opposition to be abandoned due to non-submission of evidence within two months from the service of the counter statement.

**Court Ruling:**

The court found the impugned order to be incorrect as Rule 45(1) requires evidence to be "left with the Registrar", not filed. The court ruled in favor of the appellant, stating that the tendering of evidence was a valuable commercial right and that there is no reason to assume abandonment.

**Parties:**

* **Appellant:** MS V-Guard Industries Ltd
* **Respondents:** MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd and Anr

**Source:** [PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd" from Court Records]

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 4 from PDF "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd."**

The impugned order has proceeded on a wrong premise that the evidence was not filed within two months, according to Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules (Source: PDF page 4). However, Rule 45(1) requires the evidence to be "left with the Registrar", not "filed".

**Key Facts and Decisions:**

* The applicant M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. tendered evidence in support of its opposition on August 28, 2018.
* The application for extension of time was filed under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the Trade Mark Rules.
* The learned Deputy Registrar did not consider this application while passing the impugned order.

**PDF Source:** Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000136, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021 & I.A. 178/2023 (Source: Case No. 35. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd., available on **PDF:** 35. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd..pdf

9. 
As is apparent, the impugned order has proceeded on the 
premise that, as the evidence in terms of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark 
Rules had not been filed within two months from the service of the 
counter statement of Respondent 1 on the appellant, the opposition of 
the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned by application of 
sub-rule (2) of Rule 45.  
 
10. 
At a bare glance, the impugned order is incorrect, as Rule 45(1) 
does not use the expression “filed”.  What Rule 45(1) requires is that 
the evidence must be “left with the Registrar”.  Where the statute is 
ambiguous, the benefit of ambiguity has to go to the citizen. This 
would be especially so where the statute confers a valuable 
commercial right on the citizen. It cannot be gainsaid that, having 
submitted the notice of opposition, opposing the application of 
Respondent 1 for registration of the Trade Mark, the tendering of 
evidence in support of the opposition was a valuable commercial right 
which enured in favor of the opponent/appellant. There is no 
conceivable reason as to why, having filed the notice of opposition, 
the appellant would abandon the opposition.  That the appellant did 
not, in fact, do so, is manifest by the fact that, on 28th

under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the

**Court Case:** M/S V-GUARD INDUSTRIES LTD. (Appellant) vs. M/S LIVGUARD ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES PVT LTD (Respondent)

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000136, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021

**Summary:**

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal by V-Guard Industries Ltd. against the decision of the Deputy Registrar to treat their opposition to Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd's trade mark application as abandoned.

**Background:** The evidence in support of the opposition was sent by the appellant on 8th May 2018, but it was received by the Registrar on 10th May 2018. The issue is whether there was a delay in complying with Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules and if so, whether the learned Registrar could condone or extend the time.

**Arguments:**

* Appellant argued that their attempts to e-file the evidence on 7th May 2018 failed due to a non-functional website.
* Respondent argued that Rule 45 requires compliance within two months of service of the counter statement.

**Decision:** The learned Counsel for the appellant and respondent were heard, and it was opined that the decision of the Deputy Registrar should be sustained in its entirety. It is considered that the ambiguity in Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules does not favor the Appellant's arguments.

Note: The PDF file is sourced from a court case document, and this summary focuses on key facts and legal proceedings.

Based on page 6 of the PDF "35. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd." (Court Case: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021 & I.A. 178/2023), here is a summary:

**Procedural requirements for opposing trade mark registration**

The court cites Rule 45(1) of the Trade Mark Rules, which requires an opponent to serve evidence in support of opposition within two months of receiving the counter statement filed by the applicant. The opponent must also deliver copies of the affidavit to the applicant and intimate the Registrar.

**Provision of Rule 8**

The court interprets Rule 8, which deals with service of documents at or to the Trade Marks Registry, noting that it is "nebulous" and does not provide clarity on the procedure for serving documents. However, the court decides that in this case, the applicant will not benefit from the ambiguity.

**Court's opinion**

The judge rules that the opponent must follow the procedural requirements as specified by Rule 45(1) to oppose the trade mark registration.

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Court Decision Summary**

**Case:** M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. vs. M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd.

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000136
**C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM)**: 80/2021 & I.A. 178/2021

**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Date:** January 6, 2023 ( Judgment); August 30, 2018 (impugned order)

**Parties:** Appellant - M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd., Respondents - M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. and Anr.

**Facts:**

The appellant filed an opposition to the registration of a trademark by the respondent. The learned Deputy Registrar treated the opposition as abandoned due to late receipt of evidence. The appellant argued that it had made efforts to file the evidence on time, but it was delayed. The court held that the provision requiring evidence to be filed within two months should not be interpreted rigidly.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

*   Applicant's advocate Ms. Bhabna Das argued that the opposition was valid.
*   Court rejected the idea of treating opposition as abandoned solely due to late filing of evidence.
*   Discretionary powers to extend time for opposing trademark registration were left for another court decision.
*   Impugned order dated August 30, 2018, was set aside by the court.

**Outcome:**

The learned Deputy Registrar is directed to consider the appellant's opposition and make a decision. Any registration of the mark shall remain subject to this outcome.

**Dates:**

*   January 6, 2023 - Judgment date
*   August 30, 2018 - Impugned order date

**Referral Document:** MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd vs M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd.pdf

Source: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. vs MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd (2023/DHC/000136)

Key points from page 8:

* The court upheld the right to oppose registration, noting it's as important as seeking registration.
* In this case, the appellant made efforts to provide evidence in support of opposition within the stipulated time, although a few days late.
* The court deemed it unfair to dismiss the opposition based solely on the late submission of evidence.
* The court directed the learned Deputy Registrar to consider the filed evidence and make a decision accordingly (point 26).
* Date mentioned: August 2018 (impugned order date), January 10, 2023 (Signature date).
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000136 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021                                                                       Page 8 of 9  
 
   
provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late, 
especially as, prima facie, the appellant did make efforts to “leave” the 
evidence in support of the opposition with the office of the learned 
Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.  
26. 
Resultantly, the learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take into 
account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a 
view thereon.
